reviewText:
Awakened behind the twisted metal bars of your cell suspended far above the earth, a magnificently gnarled airship humming ominously above as it carries our mysterious hooded protagonist from their unknown past to a hellish new reality behind the confines of a massive and ghastly prison complex. Will you give in to your new existence of demonic incarceration, or will you find the will to journey into the pits of hell itself and find your freedom?

Tormentum is not a tale for the queasy, with brutal depictions of death, despair, and torture the imagery within is enough to make the average modern horror fan ♥♥♥♥ their pants in terror. The game comes from a seriously engaging and tasteful angle despite this, and everything is done in a fictionally compelling way that serves the narrative and not just for the sake of shock. The core element in Tormentum is atmosphere, and its surreal influences show to the very root.

The bleak path ahead is riddled with puzzles, mini-games and secrets keeping you just out of reach of your next step to freedom, the next diabolical room of traps and tricks and all forms of unholy devices. Each solution requires a keen eye and generally has the player glossing carefully over each hand-painted environment, which is already a real treat to behold on its own. Paying close attention to small details left across the harrowing stages leads you to discovering artifacts and symbols usually arranged in specific ways to clue you in on how to solve that specific area's solution, and take form as anything from candles being lit in specific order to create a pentagram of light across carefully arranged mirror surfaces to crudely decorated skulls that must be brought back to their rightful tortured remains.

The puzzles here are genuinely fun, as someone who generally hates them I didn't find anything in Tormentum to be tedious or long-winded. They reward those with an appreciation for the remarkable art and encourages enthusiastic exploration of the visuals surrounding the player. With many obstacles come moral choices, and many of the solutions face the player with painful decisions that weigh on your mind throughout, the betrayal of friends and murders of the seemingly innocent bringing you closer to your goal but further from humanity. The spirit of classic point and click adventure gaming is present, and you'll be completing plenty of satisfyingly simple and rewarding tasks and pushing for that next gruesome screen of beautifully detailed scenery though never without consequence.

The artwork itself is absolutely breathtaking not because it is pretty, gorgeous, or inspiring but because it is fantastically grotesque in detail. Every organic curve, every sickeningly moist surface of glistening quality and every rusted jag of blackened metal stand out with each transition of a scene, each one more jaw-dropping than the last. A brutal assault of rapid images portraying ruthlessly grim imagery, making escape the one bright glimmer of hope in our protagonist's peril. There's an unmistakable similarity to some of the most macabre and surreal artists from the organically twisted curves of Giger to the grand hellscapes of Bosch, combined with the likes of what could be straight out of a Dimmu Borgir album cover just for extra measure. And it isn't just the art; I've already caught several references to works of the surreal including the phrase Fire Walk with Me"

reviewText:
Review: Tormentum - Dark Sorrow
“Act in such a way that you treat humanity, whether in your own person or in the person of any other, never merely as a means to an end, but always at the same time as an end.”

Immanuel Kant

This is what Tormentum starts with, a well known quotation from one of the most popular philosophers Germany has to offer. What defines human ethics? Is reason the source of morality? You should know by now that Tormentum neither answers this questions solely nor tries to do so, but stimulating the player’s mind with radical issues presented in gruesome but hand-painted actions and pictures instead of reading Kant’s essay might work better, at least for gamers. Your actions and decisions will affect your story, always leaving you behind with one question left. Did I make the right choice?

Introduction done. Don’t worry, this is not about philosophy, it is about Tormentum, a game that looks like our worst nightmares got caught and painted by H.R.Giger. Some of those bad dreams might even haunt you after the game is over but even then you just can’t stop looking at every small detail, whether it looks amusing, terrifying or violent. Speaking of terror and violence, we should take a look at Tormentum’s story. You are...well. Who are you? You are somebody,  yet no one. A poor creature wearing a capuchin, that gets imprisoned in an old, horrendous looking castle, threatened with torture and punishment for sins you cannot remember. Survival is your only thought and thus keeps your motivation alive even after having seen the suffering your new home has to offer. Prepare for morale choices that will not only affect yourself and keep that one thing in mind: Nobody is what they claims to be.

While Tormentum does look like a classic point-and-click at first sight, it uses some hidden object influences, mixes it up and combines them with classical puzzles and riddles. These are not unbeatable since you will find many clues but expect to be fairly challenged. May it be the right time on a watch, a certain melody that needs to be played or a man-eating worm that blocks your path, you will love the variety. There is no button for highlighting things, some objects have a unique glow instead whilst others can be hard to find sometimes. Additionally, objects can neither be combined in your inventory nor used for multiple actions. This may sounds simple but it fits the idea Tormentum wants to convey. The only time this really bothered me was early on after the start where you get confronted with many different scenes and tasks. If one link is missing in the chain you get stuck forever, running through the same backgrounds multiple times. These are eyecatchers even after passing them again and again, so do not lose  your confidence, there is a clue or hint for everything.

Before listing major points, I want to take a second look at the atmosphere Tormentum creates. I can’t talk enough about the graphics, or better, art OhNoo Studio created here. There won’t be many scenes you may find peaceful or cheering though, but would you really expect that to happen when a game is called Tormentum? You will witness pain, torture and suffering, everywhere. One can only imagine how a world would look like where evil lurks everywhere and redemption seems to be the only escape, but if this world really exists I fear it would look like Tormentum. Creepy People and Creatures, a dying land, epic but disgusting monuments, fire that rains from the sky, everything brought to life or death with hand-drawn masterpieces. Whoever created the soundtrack and effects should be awarded, too. My first impression was a bit monotonous but it quickly became the perfect skin for its cadaverous body. Emotions can be heard without even knowing what happens in the current scene.

Big Text, Quick Facts:
Pro:
Oustanding artwork, inspired by H.R.Giger and Others - brutal and otherworldly
Emotional Plot with moral choices and multiple endings - mature and philosophical
A soundtrack that captures the essence of pain and sorrow
Various Puzzles and Riddles offer good challenges - without interrupting the plot too much
Interesting side stories to learn - Nobody is what he claims to be
Con:
Every riddle has a hint - but finding those gets annoying sometimes since objects cannot be highlighted and some puzzles simply can’t be solved without the matching clue
Some things will happen - no matter which choice you made
Small bug - using steam overlay lowers the fps while writing. Chatting and Tormentum shouldn’t be combined anyway.
Summary:
Seeing this game getting Greenlit made me proud and happy since I backed it on Kickstarter myself, but when it got released the two of us couldn’t match. I am not a fan of Hidden Object games and playing the first couple of minutes I felt that this was not the game I expected. My opinion changed as you might have already guessed.

Once the story gets its hands on you, luring you with choices, challenging with puzzles, playing with morality and disturbing with violence, Tormentum starts to become more than just a piece of unforgettable sound, visuals and artwork. Staring at the screen for more than 5 minutes, pondering your next decision, you will ask yourself again: What is the right choice? Whether you know Kant or not, this will affect you.

Verdict: 8,5 / 10

reviewText:
Tormentum: Dark SorrowDeveloper: OhNoo Studio
Publisher: OhNoo Studio

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased, informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
Inspired by HR Giger's unique biomechanical style and games such as Dark Souls and Dark Seed, Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is an extremely dark point and click adventure, diving deep into themes such as damnation, sin, and redemption. While somewhat short, Tormentum is a nearly unforgettable adventure spanning across 3 different realms. Fans of this genre may find something here that rivals other titles' quality! Let's take a closer look at what Tormentum has to offer.

Gameplay
==========
As a point and click adventure, the game plays out entirely at your pace. Progression is limited by your ability to find hidden secrets and solve puzzles. This is done by clicking objects and areas on-screen to uncover them. Hidden objects are able to be picked up, stored on your bag, and used in other areas, typically assisting in solving puzzles presented to the player.

As you solve puzzles, you slowly gain access to more areas of the dark castle your character is being held prisoner in. Each area is it's own puzzle, so to speak, and by carefully examining each area will you piece together each puzzle. Some rooms have NPCs, which will help or hinder you, depending on certain factors. Usually they will give you an item needed to progress, in exchange for solving another, smaller puzzle or task. One NPC is a guard who gives you a shovel to dug up a piece of gold, and rewards you with a necklace that is actually a key to a door nearby--just as an example. There are many areas to explore, and many puzzles to solve!

An important aspect of the game is the Journal. It automatically keep notes on important bits of imformation you find, such as a diagram of a point of interest you find somewhere, or a crude drawing providing a clue left behind by another prisoner of the castle. This can be checked at anytime, as well as your bag where your items are kept.

Lastly, at certain points of the game you are presented with some moral choices, literally good or evil. Depending on your choices, you may get the good or bad ending...which is basically how your character is judged at the very end of the story. If you are aiming for a particular ending, make sure you hit all the right choices, a single mistake can change your ending entirely.

Graphics
==========
As mentioned before, Tormentum's unique art style is heavily inspired by games such as Dark Souls and Dark Deeds, and by famous painter and sculptor HR Giger.  Giger is credited with designing the monster simply known as the 'Alien' or Xenomorph from the classic 1979 film of the same name. Giger has a very unique style, blending biological and mechanical components together to create a unique blend of flesh and machine. This is prominently seen and featured in nearly every scene of Tormentum, and in most NPC designs. This style works very well for the setting.

Hand-painted stages help to blend everything together, and are a wonder to behold. Half the fun of the game is pushing onwards just to see the next area and it's art. Everything is incredibly dark and very detailed.

Sound and Music
==========
Featuring over 40 spine-tingling tracks, Tormentum has quite the soundtrack to help immerse you into the story and setting. Slow, yet hopeful tunes for the more docile scenes, with darker more evil tracks for the hellish scenes you will encounter. Nothing is amiss here, and it all comes together to create a memorable experience.

Performance
==========
For this type of game, a high framerate isn't needed, which is good because Tormentum ran at an acceptable 30FPS at all times. I did not run into any bugs, random crashes, or stuttering at any point. There are very few video/audio options, but honestly they are hardly needed.

Final Thoughts
==========
Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is an excellent point and click adventure, one you are bound to remember long after you finish it. Although short, it's filled with clever puzzles and hidden secrets. It's dark style, artwork, and soundtrack are the best features. Fans of the genre will find a very enjoyable experience with Tormentum, and anyone who isn't a fan may just be converted into one!

==========
Highly Recommended

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a point and click adventure thrown into a damnable orgy of suffering, misery and despair in the visual trappings of Giger and Beksinski.  The art is easily the linchpin of this release, those richly hellish and tortuous scenes are so morbidly captivating and visceral that one has to question the mental health of the artist. It’s not just those wide panoramic vistas that give off a sense of infernal grandeur, it’s also the attention to detail in small objects, items obscured and a wealth of visually suggestive scenery and object placement that make the art direction and presentation so incredible. Feed into that the bleak and austere soundtrack and you have an audio visual phenomenon.
Gameplay is your standard point and click adventure types, you are to find items that they may resolve other problems that hinder your progress in the game, rinse and repeat. To this end the game employs a great number of puzzles which are fairly enjoyable and not too taxing, oftentimes clues given to you on how to solve them are found in other locations. Overall the gameplay is simple and for the most part is secondary to the experience, not so much in the sense it has been neglected, but more so that it is a means to an end rather than the core of the experience.
The lore and story are slowly bled out to you, never providing you with too much detail, but just enough dark particulars to provide a minimalist context allowing your imagination to run wild and give a few grains of morality in weighing up your actions. NPC’s are often times minimalist in interaction, but are quite capable of reinforcing the central themes to the game and giving it greater depth. This overall vagueness reinforces the crushing sense of despair and disorientation that accompanies you in the game throughout.
At certain points you are presented with choices and whilst at face value they are your standard black and white good or bad dichotomy, the lack of guidance or understanding of your role in this world brings your own philosophical dilemmas into the fray. Can one kill for freedom? Is it a crime to punish the wicked? Is it my place to judge them so? Am I being lied to? Etc.
Gameplay is short, I would guess perhaps around 5 hours in total, but what an intense and rewarding 5 hours they are! Not forgetting that there is some replayability in making alternate choices in the game. However playtime is irrelevant, playing Tormentum is an experience more than a game, a quasi-philosophical interactive grotesquery of redemption and punishment set in the most horrific and stunning abysses.

reviewText:
Tormentum: Dark Sorrow (Casual Adventure)

Very simple options with this one: Sliders for music and sound effects, and full-screen or not. In addition, there are nine languages to choose from.

If you play the demo, you'll find that the game seems to be more of a puzzle game than an adventure, with just a few screens and puzzles before moving on to the next area. This does NOT hold true for the rest of the game. You'll be locked out of some areas once you leave them, but there are plenty of locations to move about, puzzles to solve, and story to discover as you progress.

There are no hints, no skips, and no map. I did not have any trouble completing the game, nonetheless. Nothing I came across was frustratingly hard, and the only real problem I had was missing obvious things on the screen, like something I needed to interact with or an exit I simply didn't see. :p

Every screen scrolls left and right a bit, depending on where your cursor is. Although it would have been nice to just see the full scenes, some of the puzzles involve this scrolling mechanism, so I can't complain.

Speaking of the puzzles, be VERY CAREFUL when you are solving them, and really pay attention to what you're doing! Sometimes there is more than one way to solve a puzzle, and your actions really matter in this game. Your decisions count, so choose wisely.

The art style is dark and disturbing, but also beautifully done and very evocative. Combine this with the well-chosen music tracks, and you have a deeply environmental experience that will question your morals and life choices.

For the achievement hunters like myself, there are 34 achievements to obtain, which will require you to play through the game at least twice. I'm pretty sure most people won't mind going through a second time, as there are two endings!

There is a lot of bonus content to look at, which is not necessary to complete the game, but will enhance the experience. Some of these things will earn your achievements (such as reading all of the books,) so be aware of that.

While Tormentum: Dark Sorrow is on the short side (around four hours for my first play-through,) the multiple endings and fascinating world which the devs have created make it absolutely worth owning. Definitely recommended, and I'm looking forward to OhNoo Studio's next game~! :D

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow was an amazing experience for me. I loved every minute of it and was a bit sad when it was over.

Game Summary
In Tormentum, you play as a hooded figure that has lost all his memories, save the memory of a dream of a strange statue on a hill. He awakens in captivity and is told he is to be punished for crimes he doesn't remember commiting. The game follows his escape and journey to the the hill from his dreams, in the hopes of restoring his memory. Along the way, he meets many strange characters, visits terrifying landscapes, and is presented with moral choices that shape his jouney, and eventually, his destiny.

Breakdown
Graphics: The art style was what caught my attention initally and is arguably the strongest asset the game. The characters, set pieces, and landscapes are all so alien, yet disturbingly beautiful. Unlocking a door or opening a new area was exciting, not just because I was progressing through the game, but because I would be rewarded with new and beautiful art that would leave me staring with a sense or wonder and horror rolled into one.

Music/Sound: The music is haunting and when combined with the art made for a really good atmosphere. The sound effects are well done, from opening of chests to the squelching of blood to the soft growl of a monstrous creature, each one felt solid and immersive.

Gameplay/Mechanics: The moral choices, while interesting, is probably where my biggest complaint with the game comes from. It was obvious in most cases which choice was good and which was evil, which I did like, because I never worried that I would make a choice that would result in an outcome I hadn't intended. However, there is no grey area: one wrong choice automatically gets you the bad ending, even if all the other choices you made were considered good. Because of this, there was almost no motivation for you to make the evil choices(except one of them where the evil choice saves you time). Not to mention the fact that (minor spoiler) you steal objects from people that call you friend" and kill several creatures.

UI/Controls: The UI is simple and minimalistic: you have an inventory bag in the lower right corner for items you find and a notepad in the lower left that copies any puzzle hints and intsructions you come across. Arrows on the sides of screens and door icons clearly highlight where you can go

reviewText:
A beautiful, dark point and click adventure with fairly straightforward puzzles.

Other reviewers have mentioned Giger and Beksiński, who I'm not familiar with, but I did feel like I was walking through a series of Hieronymous Bosch scenes. The themes of the story are ones people find timelessly fascinating and I like to think of the cost of the game as comparable to the cost of entry to an art gallery with the bonus that you now have your very own set of art installations to interact with at your leisure.

The only misbehaviour of the game was in dealing with my multi-monitor setup - where Tormentum ran happily but was not centred properly across the monitors. People with Eyefinity setups may have to revert to single monitor use. Other than that the game ran without a hitch on my Win 8 (not 8.1) system.

I think some games become precious and illogical in an effort to make their puzzles 'hard'. I am satisfied with the difficulty in Tormentum, and making the puzzles more lateral and obscure would detract from the flow and experience of this game.

There are a number of decisions the player makes in the game which affect the story and ending, and so the game will require at least 2 to 3 playthroughs to experience all the outcomes.

reviewText:
By raising $11,000 on Indiegogo, Tormentum: Dark Sorrow proves that point and click adventure games still have an audience. And at first glance, it's easy to see why: not only did OhNoo Studio create a hellishly beautiful game, they lowered the puzzle difficulty so as to appeal to a larger audience.

Speaking of puzzles, let's talk about game design. In Tormentum, players do not control their avatar directly; instead, they click left, right, up or down in order to progress through a series of moderately interactive screens. As to the puzzles themselves, they appear in two forms. The first requires players search for a particular object, such as a bone to appease a hungry animal or a key to unlock a prison cell. Secondly, Tormentum is filled with mini-games. These mini games often possess puzzle elements—for example, adjusting a set of gears to open a door—but not always.

Experienced point and click adventure fans may have noticed that I didn't mention item combinations. That's because there aren't any. OhNoo Studio ditches item combinations in order to lower their game's difficulty while providing a minimalistic inventory system. Does this decision pay off? In the end, I have to say no. The puzzle design in Tormentum never strays too far from easy, and genre veterans will breeze through this game.

That said, easy puzzles shouldn't distract from the game's biggest triumph: tone. All of the art in Tormentum is hand-drawn and disturbingly ghoulish, with many monsters seemingly torn from the pages of a H.P. Lovecraft novel. The world alternates between horrible, bleak, and ravaged. No one finds goodness in Tormentum, a sentiment echoed by the game's ominous and occasionally plaintive soundtrack.

With decent gameplay and strong art, I'd consider recommending Tormentum were it not for the game's terrible story. OhNoo Studio bundles two video game clichés with a vague plot and obvious morality system. Amnesiac protagonist? Check. Absolving murderers good and killing innocents bad? Check. The nail in the coffin is the game's English translation: though Tormentum is more or less devoid of blatant errors, several awkward phrases took me out of the story.

When I think of Tormentum, I think of missed opportunity. What if this game had put a price on being good, encouraging the player to make the evil choice instead? What if the developers had fleshed out the plot? While Tormentum: Dark Sorrow could have left me contemplating life, OhNoo Studio settled for style over substance. This point and click adventure will have its fans, but don't count me among them.

FINAL SCORE: 5.8/10

9/10 for the genre.

reviewText:
Skip to the end for a pro/con list of features. This review is spoiler-free.

Tormentum is a point & click game set in a dark world with soundtracks and art style that make it unique in its genre. The story is fairly simple and revealed slowly bit by bit, with a great twist at the end. There are no combat mechanics or even player-controlled movement, and yet at no point have I felt these things missing. You navigate the world room by room, relying on your perception to interact with your surroundings, picking up items and using objects. Collectables have a slight shine to them, which makes it a bit easier to spot them and you won't spent much time hunting down items. The game involves a lot of puzzle solving but most of them are easy enough, with only a few that can make you stuck on them (especially if you missed the hints). The graphics in this game are pure works of art, and the eerie soundtracks complete the depressing, grim feel of the world you are traversing. Every now and then you will have to make a moral choice, and these choices will essentially decide your ultimate ending. Wish the game was a bit longer, but it's not too short as it is. It would also be great if there was voice acting instead of just plain text. Overall, Tormentum has enough replayability value for at least 2 playthroughs and a total of 5-6 hours of entertainment and is in my opinion definitely worth the price.

Pros+ A well told, easy to follow story with a great twist
+ Awesome graphic style
+ Excellent soundtracks
+ Simple but powerful moral choices
+ Striking, interesting characters
+ The atmosphere is very well set and realistic

Cons- A bit short
- Most puzzles very easy
- No voice acting (except intro)

Final verdict: 8/10

But the puzzles are easier than classic point & click games and there are no dialogue trees.

This was the perfect game for me because I love mini puzzles and I HATE dialogue trees. There is dialogue, but it's concise, relevant, and interesting. The mini puzzles were cool, but not so difficult that you have to spends hours trying to solve each one. This was the first game I have played without using a walkthrough at some point. Most of the time I knew what I needed to do, and could rely on the in-game hints.

The main reason to play this game, though, is for the story. The only downside is, like most games of this type, I wish it were longer. I have 9 hours on record but most of that was from the game running in the background while I was doing other things, or asleep. Ideally I would like an adventure game to last 20 hours, but given the level of detail of the artwork, that would be unrealistic.

Edited to add: this game has no voice acting which I think is perfect. I hate voice acting unless it's really really good quality. The silence is eery and fits the atmosphere. Basically, everything about this game is perfect. I am now really sad that I've finished the game. Anyone who likes point & click games should really just buy this right away.

reviewText:
Oozing with gore and morbidity, Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is an engrossing point and click adventure that you're sure to remember for years to come. The game itself is seething with hellish nightmarescapes, and venomously dripping with macabre dialogue; a far more tortured choice compared to many of the point and clicks available on the market today. Make no mistake, this title is not for those who may get depressed easily, as it deals with some heavy subject matter and it confronts those dark, ghastly thoughts that linger in the back of our minds; forcing us to think about our life choices, and what may be waiting for us in the afterlife.

Hands down, the main focus of Tormentum is its eerily captivating artwork. The artists did one hell of an amazing job merging the soft pastels and hazy dream-like features of Zdzislaw Beksinski's work with the harsh, alien architecture of H.R. Giger. If it weren't completely impossible, I'd go as far to say that both of these renowned surrealist artists collaborated and contributed the art straight to the game. The massive amounts of detail that has been put into the artwork alone more than makes Tormentum worth the full selling price, artists as talented as the ones who worked on this title deserve high recognition and I firmly believe that true art should never be undersold. The screenshots that you will see on the store page are just a faint few of the 70+ cadaverous hand-painted expanses that you will wander across, and there are numerous devils to encounter. The entire world that has been created for Tormentum feels overwhelmingly larger than you are.

Coupling the awe inspiring artwork is a dark, brooding soundtrack. I sincerely wish that it was for sale on Steam, as I would purchase it in a heartbeat. There was actually one part of the game, near this giant tower, that I enjoyed the music so much that I cranked my speakers, left my computer and proceeded to do housework while just listening to the audio. It's rare for me to enjoy a game soundtrack this deeply, but I would actually put Tormentum's score on a regular playlist; right along side some Bethlehem, Velvet Acid Christ and Burzum. The ominous, ambient hymns bring an entire new dimension to the art style that is displayed within the game, and they really suck the gamer in while refusing to let go.

So, what is this game actually about? Sadly, I can't delve far into the story without spoiling it completely; I will say that you are a man, wandering the huge realm of Tormentum in search of a way out. Along the way you must face tough choices, all of which will ultimately matter in the end. The character that you are playing has no more knowledge than you do, and vica versa; this is much akin to plots like that of Stasis and Sanitarium. You will learn more about the hellish world that you're traversing through by reading notes and speaking with the many interactive beings within the game. Many of these fiends are quite forlorn and profound with their dialogue, which is reminiscent of The Divine Comedy by Dante. As usual, it will all make the most sense once the game has reached completion.

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow is a completely stunning macabre point and click game that will appeal to a niche audience. Art enthusiasts will absolutely love this game for its stunning in-depth visuals, audiophiles will love it for the superbly creepy soundtrack, and fans of both will completely fall in morbid love. While the story isn't anything to rave about, it will strike a chord with fans of literature along the lines of The Divine Comedy (Dante's Inferno). The only real fault that I could possibly find with Tormentum is how short it is. I finished 3 full playthroughs in roughly 6 hours, with my initial run clocking in at about 3 and a half hours. That being said, I just can't gush and go on about this title enough. It's absolutely the best point and click experience I've ever had, but then again I love H.R. Giger, Zdzislaw Beksinski, Dante's Inferno and dark ambient music. If you're a fan of any of the aforementioned things, do not hesitate to throw your money down on this twisted nightmare.

reviewText:
Tormentum is a puzzler at heart adorned in an adventure cape. Thrown into a prison for reasons unbeknownst to you, you are supposed to escape your cell and find your way out of whatever location you are in.

For all the imagination that was put on the world design, there is never really any motivation for you to do anything other than to just finish the game. You will encounter multiple characters, each with their own plea and moral standing, and depending on who you assist, the game will generate one of two different endings.

Each new location presents a puzzle or an element that you will need to solve one, and their designs are absolutely striking. So much work has been put on each set-piece and all for good reason. Simple in its approach as it is, Tormentum is a beautiful game that justifies its asking price just for its aesthetic, and at $11, coupled with some interesting puzzles, it’s a bargain.

Pros:

– Beautiful landscapes and art direction specially if you are an H.R Giger fan.

– Balanced difficulty curve that has the game starting ♥♥♥♥-easy and ending mind-numbingly challenging.

– Great use of sound and ambient

– Multiple paths that will lead to one of two different endings.

Cons

– The story is too simplistic and almost laid out for you from the outset

– Some puzzles are obtuse and others are too simplistic.

– What ending you get, evil or good, is dependent on your decisions, themselves dependent on visual cues that are not clear at times.

I just finished playing Tormentum - Dark Sorrow, and there are very few games these days that I can sit down and play for several hours at a time but this was one of these games. In fact, I sat down and didn't get up before the credits were rolling, which does say a lot about the phasing of this game. It took me about 4 hours to get through, which for me is well worth the asking price. (Might have to check out some of the other endings as well)

What really kept me engaged in this game was the fantastic setting, wonderfully rendered, incredibly creative environments and characters are scattered around. And even with very little dialogue per character you still get a great sense of who they might be by just looking around and taking in their surroundings. Presentation really sells this experience.

The only thing I could possibly comment on is the difficulty of the puzzles. This is rather difficult to predict as a game designer when using somewhat pre-used puzzle designs, how much their audience has already experienced those types of puzzles. For me having played quite a few of these games, none of the puzzles felt very challenging, so they ended up feeling a bit routine like. There is a good variety however, so at least you're not doing the same ones multiple times.

Overall, fantastic experience, one I'll be keeping with me for a while to come.
Thanks to the developers for providing something very interesting and pleasing to the mind.

TLDR: an aesthetically beautiful, simple, but short game with many flaws. Recommend a buy only if discounted or if you really like the aesthetic.

NOTE: I actually played the game for about three hours, I have less on record because I was not online when playing.

THE GOOD:
The game is, simply put, beautiful. Each area, character and object is very well designed and every scene would not look out of place as the cover of a metal album.

THE BAD:
The game is very short. I have managed two full playthroughs in three hours, the first one carried out at an extremely leisurely pace, especially consider I am not at all good at adventure/puzzle games. Most puzzles are fairly simple and with a relatively obvious solution. In the entire playthrough there was only one point where I found myself stumped (and even then it turned out I already had the item I needed and I had simply missed a detail in its description earlier). The game also has a heavy moral choice element, which is not everyone’s cup of tea.

WARNING – HEAVY ENDGAME SPOILERS FOLLOW[/b]



THE UGLY:
While the game has a marked black/white moral choice element, the “good” choice (i.e. the morally upright choice) is not always clear. Examples are the fact that it is moral to spare prison guards (even though their main/only activity is the torture of prisoners) and it is correct to give the powerful artefact to the mysterious mage that basically tells you “I will not abuse its power, like pinky swear” (he is telling the truth, but when making the choice you only have his word to go by). In several instances the choice comes down to who you believe over others, which can be fine, but i.m.o. not when a single wrong choice can lock you into the bad ending and there is no way to reload without starting a new game.

By far however my main gripe with this game is the ending: after starting the story in medias res and raising a huge amount of questions regarding the setting (who are the knights who captured you? Where do they come from? Why are they so obsessed with purging evil from others through torture?....) the endgame cops out by telling you the entire experience was a dreamlike “second chance” your character had to see if he could be worthy of redemption after his suicide. Nothing needs explanation, because everything was symbolic. From this, I am disappoint.

reviewText:
Giger and Beksinski are among my Top 5 favorite artists, so when I read and saw that this game was inspired by their art, I purchased it immediately after checking out the trailer and screenshots.

There are certainly many obvious references to Giger and Beksinski in this game's art, especially in the background and I noticed walls and statues inspired by Giger's Temple, Li and Necronom artworks, among plenty others. The art style is very grim and gritty, and the biomechanical structures of Giger's environments and the death, decay and despair prominent in Beksinski's paintings permeate every scene in this game. Skeletal beings and dark, cold machinery fuse with throbbing flesh and monstrous monuments, in a tribute to these great surreal, fantasy-horror artists.

The music in this game helps to bring the art to life and add to the atmosphere and tension that immerse the player. The sounds and ambience are foreboding and full of lonely desolation; the chanting whispers in the background combined with the loud clanking of alien machinery, or the strange rumbling and pulsating throbs barely audible; they all help the player visualize the otherworldly scenes both visible and just out of reach of the camera.

The puzzles are logical and vary greatly, and bring depth to the gameplay, which mostly consists of searching for items and matching them with other interactables in the environment, and moving from scene to scene in a classic point-and-click style.

Overall, this game is definitely worth its price and your time, especially if you are a fan of Giger and/or Beksinski. Even if you aren't, but are just wanting to explore an adventure game that truly immerses you into its atmosphere and environment through gorgeously-drawn yet disturbing artwork and darkly-beautiful music, then you should get this game too.

reviewText: Amazing art. Would love to see a second game.
A fairly simple point and click adventure with a gorgeously oppressive gothic aesthetic.

More a work of H.R. Giger inspired art than a game.

The visuals are heavily inspired by their source material, but also stand on their own with their own unique touch.  Many of the images in the game would serve well as a poster or portrait in the home of one so inclined towards the style.  The music does a great job of enhancing the somber, alien landscape and its equally alien inhabitants.

The writing is passable, serving to push the events of the story and game along, but nothing that will stick in your head when you're done playing.  The story, likewise, exists but is not worthy of remark.

It's a shame that while the art and style of the game are clearly inspired, gameplay is less so.  Puzzles in the game rely heavily on generic puzzle tropes (slider puzzles, circuit puzzles) and commonly repeat themselves.  I personally would have preferred puzzles that interacted more directly with the fascinating world this game strove so hard to create.  The game is also heavily dependent on alignment based decisions, but these choices are so black/white in nature they engender no internal discourse, save for which achievement you are aiming to unlock.

For the price, those inclined towards Giger's style will find enjoyment in this game, and I'm glad I got to experience it despite its flaws.  Those looking for a creepy game that better incorporates puzzles into its mythos may want to look towards a title like Fran Bow.

3.5 / 5

I grabbed Tormentum with a 33% discount, and didn't regret it for one second.

„Tormentum – Dark Sorrow“ has taken me on a strange trip to a creepy world of sorrow, where pain and misery become alive to punish me for my sins. The obscure story is mature as it confronts you with haunting moral questions/decisions as they not only affect your life but also the lives of others. So think good what you want to do - finally you have to take the consequences of your decisions (as in real life ...) And in the end you will look in a mirror ... And be surprised who you are … Or even shocked ? ... Are you ready to meet yourself ?

The catching atmospherical tension is created by the outstanding graphical artwork, that was inspired by the paintings of H.R. Giger and Zdzisław Beksiński. It’s even intensified by the dark melancholic soundtrack, that let's your heart sink in the groundless ocean of sorrow you will find in this world. The impressive text passages complete the atmospherical immersion. A very unique experience I never had before playing a video game !

Critics could say, that the dialogues are not synchronized (text only), that the use of animations is quite limited, that the graphics have to be more realistic and that the puzzles are not challenging enough as you get too many hints (by blinking items, a memo-book, character- and text comments). In relation to the offer this game makes to you, complaining about these blemishes is like a cheesy joke. „Tormentum – Dark Sorrow“ impresses because of it's deep atmosphere, it's unique story-desgin and line and its matureness – it has something to tell !

Tormentum - Dark Sorrow

Actions will decide the end of your journey through a dark wastland filled with Gothic Horror and wonders.

The gameplay is simple, pont and click and solve the puzzles. But dont let that fool you. Tormentum have plenty to offer, amazing art style in the likes of the late H.R. Giger. A beautiful soundtrack (which they need to sell cause its amazing!!) and a story that changes according to what you choose.... so choose wisely.

The art is obviously inspired by the paintings of Zbigniew Beksiński (sorry, it does not remind much of H.R. Giger - it is much less phallic for that.) The illustrations are top-notch, contributing greatly to the bleak setting of the game. However, there are barely any animations and the game cuts the scenes to a 3:4 format (leaving you with a black borders on the left and right of your display if it is widescreen.)

As dark as the illustrations is the setting. The corrupted landscape is full of twisted creatures and inhuman machines. It is foul, rotten, broken and crazy. It tries to explain itself in the finale, but even after that I was under the impression that it was grimdark for the sake of trying to be darker and edgier alone. The writing didn't help - you might be able to swallow it straight, but for me the dialogues sounded as written by a goth wannabe.

The game promises moral choices, and the bleak setting gives plenty of opportunities for that. You will be dealing with subjects like imprisonment, torture, murder, deceit and redemption. Unfortunately often the choices fall flat - since everything around you seems like an irrational nightmare there doesn't seem to be much incentive to care either way. However, your choices do influence the development of the story and do carry consequence for that twisted world.

Since you are constantly lost in the mad landscapes I was afraid that I would be similarly lost if the game's puzzles would follow a similar dream logic. However the game makes some effort to explain whys and hows of the crazy inhabitants and the machines littering the environs. It might not exactly make sense, but you should always know what to do. Why is the red ruby, that you snatched from the painting, used in a mechanism opening a door, and why is that mechanism located three floors below said door... that is a completely different question.

The game is rather easy. No puzzles are challenging to begin with, and for most of them there are solutions to be found nearby. There is however a good variety of those tiny logical puzzles, so you are constantly treated to something new. In the end, the game is rather short. The first playthrough took me 3 hours. However, I intend to give it another go to see the results of the other decisions. Replaying it will bring me closer to the advertised 4-6 hours of gameplay.

A solid casual adventure game with dark themes and great illustrations.

Tormentum-Dark Sorrow is a 2d point and click adventure with a dark and malevolent theme. The interface is clean and streamlined, and the game itself is fairly simplistic. You start off as a prisoner that goes on a journey of discovery through wastelands, purgatory, and redemption. It is evident that you have some sort of amnesia, but I found overall that the progression or motivation was hampered by too much missing story, information/lore along the way. It felt as if half the game went by when I blinked, as you are left not really knowing the deeper meanings of what was going on. Some of these questions in the end were answered, but not all. There was little if any lore or backstory, and it felt empty and slightly frustrating to want to know more about the world or my character, but was unable to.

The unique art style and atmosphere made this game enjoyable. It was original and intriguing, but didn't overdo the sense of horror or the bizarre. The atmosphere of the world synergized very well together.

One unique element to the game was that choices you make throughout the game will impact how it ends. Nothing huge or game changing,  but it was spread out and implemented well. Some of the choices might not have the impact you expected, which was misleading to say the least. You are presented with a truly evil man, for example, and your choice to kill him or let him live might not be judged as guilty or innocent as you think it would.

The gameplay is heavy on puzzles, with some scavenging quests thrown in. I would say about 75% of the items needed for scavenging come from previous quests. I find this refreshing, as it relies more on puzzles and mini-games, instead of find the safety deposit box in a room of 500 safety deposit boxes". The puzzles were smooth and continuous

This point and click game has is a special one. I think it does everything right, and more. This happens very seldom in games, but here I feel that the creators had a vision and made it from the depths of their, to a relative extent wicked, hearts. They pay no attention to what a general public of gamers prefer. This game is dark, sometimes utterly depressing, if you care to delve into surroundings, atmosphere, and what you see and read. The game has a great artistic style that alone sets the mood. On top of that there is a fantastic dark ambient soundtrack that fits the setting very well. It may sound strange, but this game made me think and dwell on things in life I wouldn't have otherwise. It has a certain amount of philosphy and psychology in it, and is to some extent intellectually challenging.

And a few words about the gameplay itself: it is a standard point and click game with puzzles on easy/medium difficulty. reviewText:
Do you like Giger-esque art? Who doesn't? It's unique, erotic and morbidly appealing.

But do you also like:
-music/sound so uninspired that you might as well be playing on mute?
-puzzles that have all the challenge of fitting a square peg into a square bore?
-to be faced with the same exact (and only) choice of kill/spare over and over?
-to feel no connection with your environment/actions/character as you perform mundane, arbitrary tasks?
-to have no understanding of the context of your journey until the last 30 seconds of exposition reveal everything (which isn't much)?
-to pay $10 for 3 hours, give or take, of gameplay that only adds up to that much because of all the mindless clicking and dragging you'll have to do?
-to find out that what's depicted in the preview trailer/pictures constitutes 85% of the game?
-to read poorly written and/or translated text, lightly sprinkled with typos?

I could go on, but I have more important writing to do. My advice: play the demo and mentally multiply that experience by 3. That's 75% of the game. Don't be lead astray by the 'what-happens-next' ending in the demo...what's behind the door is 2 more rounds of the same crap and then another 2 but in a different environment. This game is worth $2.50 tops and the art really isn't that great. It's Giger-esque only in style. Not in quality.

reviewText:
High above in the sky, locked in a cage in your gown of shadows, held from the most steampunk aircraft ever seen in a game before, across from a beauty and the beast esk monster, is where you begin this dark point and click adventure. You play as an unnamed character in dark robes, who has been captured by the dark guardians of the tower for some treason that your soul has committed. The lore and story are slowly explained to the player, that never really gives the player too much detail, creating a minimalist effect that really made the gameplay experience enjoyable. I feel like some point and click games today flood the player with story, so playing this was a sigh of relief.

The gameplay in Tormentum follows the basic structure of point and click adventure type games. Items are found that you can pick up and put in your backpack, that might solve some of the puzzles later on in the game. This process is repeated throughout the entire game, but is kept interesting with the great number of interesting and enjoyable puzzles. Most of the time, there are cheat sheets in other locations that provide the player with graphical representations of how to complete a puzzle in a different area. This keeps the games difficulty balanced and gameplay enjoyable.

The artstyle is unique and breathtaking when first seen, because it doesn't follow the conventional scheme of pretty games today, because Tormentum is incredibly grotesque in its detail. Every point of detail in the game has something amazing on it. The tables with blood dripping of them, to the human remains being electrocuted in the death chambers, each scene is as amazing as the last.

The player enters a throne room with a rather wicked looking court jester sitting by the castle throne. You approach him and he tells you to kill a certain prisoner with this special knife he provides you, whilst offering the player a hefty reward. At this point in the game, the story hadn’t been described to me that much, and so I had to make the choice that my guy told me too. These choices are dark, and usually represent a good/evil decision the player needs to make.

The games length is around 5 hours for a single playthrough. These 5 hours weren’t just a 5 hour grind of ‘gotta go here’ and ‘gotta do this’ but instead was an intense and rewarding diegetic experience. This game has plenty of  replayability with the choice system inbedded in the game, giving each playthrough a different experience. Tormentum is less a video game you play for enjoyment and more an experience that people of dark adventure would love. I would recommend Tormentum to anybody who sounds like this would be their style of game, and when it’s selling for a price point of less than $15 AUD, it’s a steal.

Let's get started with saying this game can be described as a disturbing, sick, abnormal, and a worrisome looking game. I guess that could be your opinion, but I think Tormentum - Dark Sorrow looks amazing. Every area looks like a classic heavy metal album cover coming to life! I'm a metal fan so this is right up my alley, but what's interesting is that the game's main soundtrack I wouldn't say is metal. It still fit perfectly as an eerie melody that made the life of the game intense.

Alright so you know how much I like the look, but what is the actual game. At its core it's a point and click game with smaller puzzles blended in to keep things interesting. The puzzles were exactly how I like them in a point and click game. Challenging, but not to the point where you feel the guilt to check a guide.

The smaller puzzles I mentioned are pretty straightforward. Like moving some cogs around to connect two ends, or figuring out a jig saw type puzzle. They were a nice change up from going from place to place. There's also times you'll come across patterns mentioned on signs, and other places. This is where the notebook you carry comes in handy. Your character will automatically sketch out the details. Now you can look at this pattern at anytime while looking at a puzzle that requires notes.

I want to mention this, but not going to spend too much time on it for worry of possibly taking some mystery out of the game from you. Tormentum features some choices throughout the game, and let's just say there is more than one ending. I loved the ending I got to this game, and that's all I'm going to say.

You can probably tell that I enjoyed Tormentum - Dark Sorrow a lot, but I have some issues I want to bring up. The main one is that I feel like there isn't enough options in the game. There's a couple like volume control, language selection, and a full screen mode. One option for a monitor resolution would be nice. I would have liked the game to take up more of my monitor. As you can see it there's black around the square of gameplay. I would have liked to have the option to do some sort of zoom in to take up more monitor space.

The other option I would have liked is the ability to control the camera, and make it stay still for the most part. Whenever you move your mouse the screen moves a little. It's not a big complaint, but took me a little time to get used to it. Then the last thing is more of a small annoyance. Everytime you pick up an item it zooms into it. While most of the time this feels right because it goes into more detail, it's not always necessary. When someone would give me an item it'd just be easier to just pick it up off the ground, than have to zoom in to do it. Also once you zoom out you can't zoom back into that area the item was in so I think it's a little unnecessary. These complaints in no way ruined the game. I just want to make this clear. There just things I'd would have liked to see in the game.

Final Say: I'm positive about Tormentum - Dark Sorrow. I gotta recommend it to you if you're a fan of point and click games. I do wish it was longer as it took me three hours to beat it, but there is more than one ending. So the replay value is there if you want it. Still with the artwork, music, puzzles, and story, Tormentum - Dark Sorrow gets my approval.

What I can tell you is that this is a bloody point and click adventure. You are a nameless, hooded, being that has been captured by a group that is hell-bent of purifying the world, and the way to do that, of course, is through torture.

There's going to be many obstacles and different types of puzzles put in your way, but I'm confident that if you pay attention to your surroundings you might be able to find hints to help you conquer some of the more difficult ones.

This game is around 2 and half hours in length, and when I got to the end I was both relieved and saddened. I wish that there was more because I was so invested in the game, but at the same time I was relieved that I had reached the end. Speaking of ends, there are multiple endings to this game, so if you are looking to maybe correct some of the actions you did in the game, you might be able to change your ending.

With all this being said, I have to say get this game. Mature point-and-click adventures are coming back, and I couldn't be happier.

P&Cs have a (deserved) reputation as being full of obtuse puzzles that are more about reading the designer's mind than using a realistic problem solving approach. I'm happy to report that isn't the case here. Each puzzle (and there are quite a lot of them) has a well-conveyed goal and comes together logically. For every minigame you've seen before -- slide the blocks, connect the wires, or match the tiles -- there's another that's new and interesting, and even the familiar ones often come with a twist.

For me, games are first and formost about offering the player a new world to explore, and Tormentum delivers beautifully on that end. I'll admit I groaned when my character played the amnesia card at the very beginning, but it works out surprisingly well -- this world is as alien to him as it was to me. It's a bizarre setting full of creatures and locales both otherworldly and twistedly familiar, yet everything is presented in such an unassuming, matter-of-fact way that it never stops feeling believable. It's a world you're dropped into without any explanation - because you don't need one. No lore-heavy monologues or lists of invented names to be found here. It's about as earnest and unpretentious a fantasy setting as I've ever seen.

I like the inclusion of moral choices, though they can be a little too obvious -- I don't personally subscribe to the belief that there is no right and wrong, only shades of grey"

Tormentum gets a thumbs-up from me.  The art is beautifully disturbing and the mood and atmosphere are pleasantly creepy.  While the game is moderately short, it is definitely worth taking the time to find and appreciate the details, both in the art and the information about the world & characters.

The puzzles are simple and amusing (not what I would consider challenging or frustrating), but add an extra layer that tends to augment the story and world.  This is a positive aspect in my opinion since the game is a work emphasizing morality and consequence of choice.  While the choice tree is binary in nature, the end results are less so, and choices cause the story to 'ripple' in different ways as you progress.

I would certainly describe this as a casual game, and this is supported by its well-considered design that a) does not require the player to manually save the game and b) does not allow the player to get 'stuck' and have to restart.

The story was interesting and, to my surprise, actually managed to keep a few tidbits hidden from me until the very end.  Speaking of which, the ending (at least to me) was above average and included an interesting slant.

All Steam achievements are able to be obtained within two or three playthroughs, each of which get progressively faster since the player knows what choices they intend to make ahead of time.  This is why I would recommend focusing on playing the game 'naturally' on the first playthrough, instead of immediately focusing on achievement farming.  You will likely get more enjoyment out of it that way.

For some (primarily those intrigued with the art and atmosphere), the game will be worth the full price.  For others who are still interested but edgy about its short duration, pick it up during a sale.  You will still enjoy it.

Overall, Tormentum is definitely a recommended game for casual play.

The fact that I'd never heard of this game before yesterday is proof that I'm following the wrong kinds of game news outlets. It's lavishly detailed, dripping with atmosphere, and full of the sort of weird, imaginative, borderline nightmarish imagery that I'm always on the lookout for. Mature point-and-click adventures are coming back, and I couldn't be happier.

P&Cs have a (deserved) reputation as being full of obtuse puzzles that are more about reading the designer's mind than using a realistic problem solving approach. I'm happy to report that isn't the case here. Each puzzle (and there are quite a lot of them) has a well-conveyed goal and comes together logically. For every minigame you've seen before -- slide the blocks, connect the wires, or match the tiles -- there's another that's new and interesting, and even the familiar ones often come with a twist.

For me, games are first and formost about offering the player a new world to explore, and Tormentum delivers beautifully on that end. I'll admit I groaned when my character played the amnesia card at the very beginning, but it works out surprisingly well -- this world is as alien to him as it was to me. It's a bizarre setting full of creatures and locales both otherworldly and twistedly familiar, yet everything is presented in such an unassuming, matter-of-fact way that it never stops feeling believable. It's a world you're dropped into without any explanation - because you don't need one. No lore-heavy monologues or lists of invented names to be found here. It's about as earnest and unpretentious a fantasy setting as I've ever seen.

I like the inclusion of moral choices, though they can be a little too obvious -- I don't personally subscribe to the belief that there is no right and wrong, only shades of grey"
